awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Investigations in Classical and Quantum Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will aim at making significant contributions to several areas within gravitational physics. The topics range from understanding the signals observed by gravitational wave detectors such as NSF's Laser Interferometric Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO) and the European Virgo, to studying the nature of black holes and the origin of the Universe. As with the past research supported by ongoing NSF grants, these results are likely to feature as highlights in interdisciplinary conferences, enhancing communication between diverse communities. Research funded by this grant will also add to human resources in STEM disciplines since post-docs and students will acquire diverse skills, including advanced computational and modeling techniques.

Research  supported  by this grant will cover the following main themes: (i) Gravitational waves. Recent discoveries at LIGO have opened a brand new window on the universe.  The first set of projects in the proposed research will lay down foundations for production and propagation of gravitational waves in the realistic context of the accelerating universe with dark energy, which we inhabit. (ii) A second set of projects will focus on quantum mechanical properties of black holes. In the classical world of general relativity, black holes are sinks of matter, energy and information. But they evaporate through emission of quantum radiation. There is a general agreement that energy is conserved in this process but there has been an ongoing debate on whether information is still lost, or if it is fully encoded in the quantum radiation that is emitted. Previous work supported by this ongoing NSF grant strongly suggests that quantum gravity effects will  remove the `singularity' at the center of the black hole, thereby clearing the way for information --that appeared to be lost there-- to come out.  Details of this process will be worked out. (iii) The third project involves the very early universe. In the currently accepted cosmological paradigms, quantum physics is indispensable in the very early phase of the universe, and yet, soon thereafter it is customary to assume that the universe behaves classically, as in general relativity.  How this classical behavior can emerge, and why all the subtleties and intricacies of quantum physics can be ignored, are issues of great interest both for foundational reasons and for bridging theory with observations. They will be addressed using a combination of methods from quantum field theory in curved space-times, equations governing dynamics of the early universe and geometric formulation of quantum mechanics. (iv) All three projects discussed above are of deep interest to researchers working at the interface of philosophy and frontiers of physical science, particularly general relativity, cosmology and quantum physics.  The results will be discussed at conferences and workshops in these fields, and serve to train young scientists and philosophers in both disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: This project made significant contributions to several areas within physics, astronomy, mathematics and philosophical implications of cutting-edge scientific discoveries. Specifically, the main themes of research were the following:

(i) Gravitational Waves: Recent discoveries at the Laser Interferometric Observatories (LIGO) have opened a brand-new window on the universe. The first set of projects provided novel techniques to test the accuracy of the waveform models that are being used by LIGO and to improve them.  The underlying idea is to use certain `balance laws' that result from exact Einstein's equations. The second set of projects provided foundations for a new framework to describe production and propagation of gravitational waves in the realistic context of the accelerating universe with `dark energy', that we inhabit.

(ii) The Big Bang:  Equations of general relativity break down at the big-bang and classical physics simply stops. In particular, if one probe the big bang with classical particles, one finds that their trajectories come to an abrupt halt and tidal forces between them become infinite. But what if we probe the big bang with more realistic quantum probes? A set of projects used quantum fields as probes to see if their evolution also breaks down. It was shown that it does not. Thus, the big bang is much more tame when probed with quantum fields. These results open new windows to (a) extend the known quantum field theory to physically interesting singular space-times where is was this far presumed to break down; and (b) bridge semi-classical gravity where matter is treated quantum mechanically but space-time geometry classically with full quantum gravity where space-time geometry is also quantum mechanical.

(iii) The Early Universe and the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB): Over the last three decades, the structure of the early universe has been explored by measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) by several satellite missions. In broad terms, observations are in agreement with standard theoretical predictions, in particular the inflationary scenario. However, there are also some anomalous features. While the statistical significance of any one anomaly is low, taken together they imply that in the probability distribution predicted by standard inflation, we live in a very exceptional universe. The Planck satellite team that has provided us with the most accurate CMB data to date has emphasized that it would be very desirable if these anomalies could be alleviated by some primordial physics that is not captured by standard inflation. Loop quantum gravity --a leading approach to unify general relativity with quantum physics-- predicts that the big bang is naturally replaced by a big bounce because to strong repulsive features of quantum origin that come into play only near the putative big bang.  Quantum gravity dynamics between the bounce and onset of inflation introduces novel quantum effects. Detailed analysis carried out through several projects showed that these effects do alleviate two of the most prominent anomalies naturally. Thus, quantum gravity is no longer an abstract mathematical subject; its physical ramifications can be seen through CMB observations. We have signatures of quantum gravity in the sky!

(iv)  Black Holes: The PI and his group worked on several aspects of black holes. On the classical side, they provided a description of black hole horizons in which the horizon shape and spin structure are encoded in a tower of numbers (called multipoles) in an intrinsic manner. This facilitates comparisons between results of different numerical simulations that typically use different coordinates and other auxiliary structures.  This work has opened the door for gravitational wave tomography to infer dynamical properties of black hole horizons ?which cannot be directly observed?using gravitational waves emitted when black holes merge. On another front, the PI also explored quantum properties of black holes ?how quantum effects tame black hole singularities predicted by Einstein?s general relativity and how paradoxes associated with ?information loss? can be addressed systematically.


Broader Impact:  Several metrics show that this research has had considerable impact both within and outside the gravitational physics community. For example, the PI and members of his group were invited to present their results at ~40 national and international meetings during the tenure of this grant. The PI also gave series of lectures on gravitational waves and loop quantum gravity at summer schools. The work on the early universe and black holes was also appeared in semi-popular press: some ~40 news stories have appeared (in the APS publication Physics, Science daily, Forbes, Physics.org, ?., and the Spanish and Russian press) and the key papers themselves were in the top 5% of all research outputs scored by Altmetric. During the tenure of this grant, the PI made the following contributions to human resources: he mentored three Ph. D. students (two of them female, one of whom already holds a faculty position), and four postdocs.
